abstracts.cdata!:
The primary objective of this
            environmental assessment is to conduct a quantitative and
            qualitative analysis of various environmental impacts from
            the Wuhan Urban Transport Project by investigating and
            monitoring physical-chemical, biological, and socio-economic
            environments in the project area with broad public
            participation. To mitigate the impact of road traffic noise
            and vibrations, the plan suggests using asphalt-concrete and
            bitumen as paving material in roads, particularly those
            adjacent to vulnerable buildings. Daily road maintenance
            will reduce added vibrations. After project operation,
            vehicle emissions, oil leakage, and silt left from vehicle
            tires will form runoff which, when combined with rainwater,
            will discharge into water bodies. However, the negative
            impact is expected to be low. During road construction,
            existing vegetation will be protected, and trees removed
            will be replanted. A greenbelt will be built and special
            flowers and plants added for aesthetics. Project
            construction will have no impact on bird habitats located in
            the wetlands of East Lake if motor noise is reduced by roads
            paved with high-quality bitumen. Viaducts are proposed to
            reduce impacts on fish and other aquatic animals within the
            ecological system. Temporary exits, crosswalks, bypasses,
            and underground passages will separate pedestrians from
            construction areas. Signal lights and speed limits will be
            used to control traffic flow. Hazardous substances causing
            risks of contamination, radiation, fire, and explosion, will
            be stored in troughs and bins, and specially protected
            during transport, loading, and storage, including special
            packaging and assembling specifications, temperature
            controls, added inhibitors, and radiation shields. Emergency
            procedures will be drafted to handle accidents caused by
            toxic chemicals. Other countermeasures for risk containment
            include fastening and sealing containers, requiring
            personnel to wear protective gear, restricting trucks
            carrying dangerous loads to underpopulated areas. Drainage
            systems will divert and treat sewage and rainwater. Solid
            waste will be handled according to set specifications (water
            sprayed on dust, providing retaining walls when removing old
            houses, recycling construction materials, covering waste
            when being transported, collecting household garbage for
            treatment, etc.).
